Python is learned by writing Python.

Small steps → consistency → real projects.

docs.title: Python¶
docs.text: Python is one of the most popular and versatile programming languages in the world. Known for its simplicity, readability, and extensive ecosystem, Python is widely used in software engineering, data science, web development, machine learning, and automation. It serves as both an excellent beginner’s language and a powerful tool for professionals.

docs.title: 1. What Is Python?¶
docs.text:
Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991. It was designed with the philosophy of code readability and clear syntax, often described as “executable pseudocode.”

Python’s design emphasizes:

  • Simplicity and minimalism
  • Expressive syntax
  • Support for multiple paradigms (procedural, object-oriented, and functional programming)
  • Large standard library
  • Portability across operating systems

docs.title: 2. Why Is Python So Popular?¶
docs.text:
Python’s popularity comes from several practical advantages:

Feature Description Readable Syntax Python code reads like plain English, making it ideal for beginners. Cross-Platform Runs on Windows, macOS, Linux, and embedded systems like Raspberry Pi. Huge Ecosystem Thousands of open-source libraries for every domain. Community Support A vibrant global community contributes tutorials, tools, and extensions. Integration Works easily with C/C++, Java, databases, and web APIs.

docs.title: 3. Key Features¶
docs.text:
1. Interpreted No need for compilation — Python executes code line by line.

  2. Dynamic Typing You don’t have to declare variable types explicitly.

x = 42
x = "Hello"  # same variable name, different type

  1. Indentation-Based Syntax Code blocks are defined by indentation, not curly braces.

    if x > 0:
    print("Positive")
else:
    print("Non-positive")

  2. Object-Oriented Everything in Python is an object — even functions and modules.

  3. Extensive Standard Library Python comes with modules for file I/O, math, networking, web servers, regular expressions, and more.

docs.title: 4. The Python Interpreter¶
docs.text:
Python is interpreted, meaning you can run code directly from a terminal or script file. There are several ways to execute Python:

  • Interactive mode

    >>> print("Hello, World!")
Hello, World!

  • Script mode

    python3 myscript.py

  • Notebook environment (e.g., Jupyter Notebook for data science)

You can also embed Python inside C/C++ programs or call C code from Python for performance-critical tasks.

docs.title: 5. Python Versions¶
docs.text:
Python has two major branches:

  • Python 2.x — legacy (no longer supported since 2020)

  • Python 3.x — the current and recommended version

You can check your version using:

python3 --version

docs.title: Variables and Data Types¶
docs.text:
a = 10              # int
b = 3.14            # float
c = "Python"        # string
d = [1, 2, 3]       # list
e = {"key": "value"}  # dictionary

docs.title: Functions¶
docs.text:
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("World"))

docs.title: Loops and Conditions¶
docs.text:
for i in range(5):
    if i % 2 == 0:
        print(i)

docs.title: Classes and Objects¶
docs.text:
class Animal:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def speak(self):
        print(f"{self.name} makes a sound")

cat = Animal("Kitty")
cat.speak()

docs.title: 7. The Python Ecosystem¶
docs.text:
Python’s ecosystem is enormous. Some of the most used libraries include:

Domain Popular Libraries Web Development Django, Flask, FastAPI Data Science NumPy, pandas, SciPy, Matplotlib Machine Learning scikit-learn, TensorFlow, PyTorch Automation Selenium, Requests, BeautifulSoup System Programming os, subprocess, argparse Education / CS Basics turtle, random, math

You can install packages using the built-in pip tool:

pip install numpy

docs.title: 8. Python in Real Life¶
docs.text:
Python is used by many organizations and industries:

  • Google: backend services and machine learning

  • Netflix: data analytics and recommendations

  • NASA: simulation and automation

  • Instagram: backend infrastructure

  • Spotify: data pipelines and AI recommendations

Its versatility allows developers to move between domains without learning a completely new language.

docs.title: 9. Development Tools¶
docs.text:
Some popular development environments for Python include:

  • VS Code — lightweight and extensible

  • PyCharm — professional IDE from JetBrains

  • Jupyter Notebook — ideal for experiments and data visualization

  • IDLE — simple built-in editor that comes with Python

docs.title: 10. Python and CS Education¶
docs.text:
Python is often chosen as the first programming language in universities and online courses because:

  • It minimizes syntactic overhead.

  • It emphasizes algorithmic thinking.

  • It provides immediate feedback via REPL.

  • It’s used across many computer science subfields (systems, AI, data, etc.).

In your CS101 journey, Python will help you understand control flow, data structures, and modular programming before exploring lower-level languages like C or assembly.

docs.title: 11. Python on Raspberry Pi¶
docs.text:
Python is the default language of the Raspberry Pi platform. You can use it to control GPIO pins, sensors, motors, and other hardware components.

Example:

import RPi.GPIO as GPIO
GPIO.setmode(GPIO.BCM)
GPIO.setup(18, GPIO.OUT)
GPIO.output(18, True)

This makes Python an ideal language for IoT projects and embedded system prototyping.

docs.title: 12. Summary¶
docs.text:
Python’s philosophy — “Simple is better than complex.” — reflects its design and its community spirit. It has become a foundation of modern computing, bridging academia, industry, and personal projects alike.

Whether you are:

  • learning to code for the first time,

  • building automation scripts,

  • analyzing data, or

  • deploying a web app —

Python is a language that grows with you.

Further Reading

  • Official Python Website

  • Python Tutorial (Docs)

  • Real Python Guides

  • Python Packaging User Guide

docs.title: 1. What Is XPath?
docs.text:
XPath (XML Path Language) is a query language used to locate elements in HTML/XML documents.

In Python web crawling, XPath is commonly used with libraries like:

  • lxml (most popular & powerful)
  • Scrapy (built on lxml)
  • parsel (Scrapy selector)

XPath allows you to precisely extract data such as:

  • Titles
  • Links
  • Images
  • Prices
  • Tables
  • Any structured content in a web page

docs.title: 2. Why Use XPath Instead of Regex?
docs.text:
Feature XPath Regex Structured HTML ✅ Excellent ❌ Poor Readability ✅ Clear ❌ Hard Maintenance ✅ Easy ❌ Fragile Nested elements ✅ Strong ❌ Weak

👉 Rule of thumb: Use XPath for HTML structure, Regex only for plain text.

docs.title: Install Required Library
docs.text: pip install lxml

docs.title: Minimal Example
docs.text:
from lxml import etree

html = """
<html>
    <body>
        <h1>Hello XPath</h1>
        <a href="https://example.com">Example</a>
    </body>
</html>
"""

tree = etree.HTML(html)

docs.title: 4.1 Absolute vs Relative Path
docs.text:
Expression Meaning /html/body/h1 Absolute path //h1 Anywhere in document 
tree.xpath('//h1/text()')

docs.title: 4.2 Selecting Elements
docs.text: XPath Description //a All <a> elements //div/p <p> inside <div> //* All elements

docs.title: 5.1 Extract Text
docs.text:
tree.xpath('//h1/text()')

Result:

['Hello XPath']

docs.title: 5.2 Extract Attributes
docs.text:
tree.xpath('//a/@href')

Result:

['https://example.com']

docs.title: 6.1 By Attribute Value
docs.text:
//a[@href]
//a[@class="nav"]

docs.title: 6.2 contains() (Most Used)
docs.text:
//a[contains(@href, "example")]
//div[contains(@class, "content")]

docs.title: 6.3 Multiple Conditions
docs.text: //a[contains(@href, "news") and contains(@class, "item")]

docs.title: 7. Position and Indexing
docs.text:
⚠️ XPath index starts from 1, not 0.

//li[1]      # first
//li[last()] # last
//li[position() <= 3]

Example:

tree.xpath('//li[1]/text()')

docs.title: 8.1 Parent Node
docs.text: //span/parent::div

docs.title: 8.2 Following Sibling
docs.text: //h2/following-sibling::p

docs.title: 8.3 Preceding Sibling
docs.text: //h2/preceding-sibling::p

docs.title: 9. Real Crawling Example (Requests + XPath)
docs.text:
import requests
from lxml import etree

url = "https://example.com"
response = requests.get(url, timeout=10)
response.encoding = "utf-8"

tree = etree.HTML(response.text)

titles = tree.xpath('//h1/text()')
links = tree.xpath('//a/@href')

print(titles)
print(links)

docs.title: 10. Common XPath Patterns (Cheat Sheet)
docs.text: Goal XPath All text //text() Images //img/@src Links //a/@href Class contains //*[contains(@class,"item")] Table rows //table//tr Form inputs //input/@value

docs.title: 11. Handling Missing Elements Safely
docs.text:
title = tree.xpath('//h1/text()')
title = title[0] if title else None

docs.title: Use Browser DevTools
docs.text:
1. Open page in Chrome
  2. Press F12
  3. Select an element
  4. Right-click → Copy → Copy XPath
  5. Optimize it manually

👉 Tip: Avoid absolute XPath copied directly from browser.

docs.title: 13. XPath vs CSS Selector (Quick Comparison)
docs.text:
Feature XPath CSS Parent selection ✅ Yes ❌ No Text extraction ✅ Yes ❌ No Complex logic ✅ Strong ⚠ Limited

👉 For crawlers: XPath is usually more powerful.

docs.title: 14. Common Beginner Mistakes
docs.text: ❌ Using absolute XPath ❌ Overusing // everywhere ❌ Forgetting XPath index starts at 1 ❌ Assuming element always exists

docs.title: 15. When You Are Ready for Next Level
docs.text:
Next steps after mastering XPath:

  • Combine XPath + Regex
  • Use Scrapy selectors
  • Handle AJAX-loaded pages
  • Anti-crawler strategies
  • Pagination crawling

docs.title: 16. Summary
docs.text:
• XPath is essential for Python web crawlers
  • Learn:
    • //
    • text()
    • @attribute
    • contains()
  • Practice on real websites
  • Keep XPath simple & robust

docs.title: 1. What Is Flask?
docs.text:
Flask is a lightweight Python web framework used to build web applications and APIs.

Key features:

  • Simple and easy to learn
  • Minimal and flexible (micro-framework)
  • Uses Python
  • Perfect for small projects, APIs, and learning web development

Flask does not force a project structure or many dependencies—you add only what you need.

docs.title: 2. Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before learning Flask, you should know:

  • Basic Python (functions, variables, imports)
  • How to use the terminal
  • Basic HTTP concepts (URL, request, response)

Check Python version:

python3 --version

Recommended: Python 3.8+

docs.title: 3. Installing Flask
docs.text: It’s best to use a virtual environment.

docs.title: 3.1 Create a virtual environment
docs.text:
python3 -m venv venv

Activate it:

source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: 3.2 Install Flask
docs.text:
pip install flask

Verify installation:

python -c "import flask; print(flask.__version__)"

docs.title: 4. Your First Flask App (Hello World)
docs.text:
Create a file named app.py:

from flask import Flask

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/")
def hello():
    return "Hello, Flask!"

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run(debug=True)

Run the app:

python app.py

Open your browser:

http://127.0.0.1:5000/

You should see:

Hello, Flask!

docs.title: 5. Understanding the Code
docs.text:
from flask import Flask

Imports the Flask class.

app = Flask(__name__)

Creates a Flask application instance.

@app.route("/")

Defines a route (URL path).

def hello():
    return "Hello, Flask!"

Function that handles requests to /.

app.run(debug=True)

Starts the development server.

  • debug=True enables auto-reload and error messages.

docs.title: 6.1 Basic Routes
docs.text:
@app.route("/about")
def about():
    return "About Page"

Visit:

/about

docs.title: 6.2 Dynamic Routes
docs.text:
@app.route("/user/<name>")
def user(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

Example:

/user/Alice
/user/Bob

docs.title: 6.3 Route with Type
docs.text:
@app.route("/post/<int:post_id>")
def post(post_id):
    return f"Post ID: {post_id}"

Common converters:

  • int
  • float
  • string
  • path

docs.title: 7. HTTP Methods (GET, POST)
docs.text: By default, Flask routes accept GET only.

docs.title: 7.1 GET and POST Example
docs.text:
from flask import request

@app.route("/login", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def login():
    if request.method == "POST":
        return "Logging in..."
    return "Login Page"

docs.title: 8. Templates (HTML with Jinja2)
docs.text: Flask uses Jinja2 for templates.

docs.title: 8.1 Project Structure
docs.text:
project/
│── app.py
└── templates/
    └── index.html

docs.title: 8.2 HTML Template (templates/index.html)
docs.text:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <title>Flask</title>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Hello {{ name }}</h1>
</body>
</html>

docs.title: 8.3 Render Template in Flask
docs.text:
from flask import render_template

@app.route("/")
def home():
    return render_template("index.html", name="Flask")

docs.title: 9.1 Structure
docs.text:
project/
│── app.py
│── templates/
│── static/
    └── style.css

docs.title: 9.2 CSS File (static/style.css)
docs.text:
body {
    background-color: #f4f4f4;
}

docs.title: 9.3 Use in HTML
docs.text: <link rel="stylesheet" href="{{ url_for('static', filename='style.css') }}">

docs.title: 10.1 HTML Form
docs.text:
<form method="post">
    <input type="text" name="username">
    <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>

docs.title: 10.2 Flask Code
docs.text:
from flask import request

@app.route("/submit", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def submit():
    if request.method == "POST":
        username = request.form["username"]
        return f"Hello, {username}"
    return render_template("form.html")

docs.title: 11. Returning JSON (API)
docs.text:
Flask is great for APIs.

from flask import jsonify

@app.route("/api/user")
def api_user():
    return jsonify({
        "name": "Alice",
        "age": 20
    })

docs.title: 12.1 Custom 404 Page
docs.text:
@app.errorhandler(404)
def not_found(error):
    return "Page not found", 404

docs.title: 13. Project Structure (Recommended)
docs.text:
project/
│── app.py
│── templates/
│── static/
│── venv/
│── requirements.txt

Generate dependencies:

pip freeze > requirements.txt

docs.title: 14. Flask vs Django (Brief)
docs.text: Feature Flask Django Complexity Simple Full-featured Flexibility High Opinionated Learning Curve Easy Steeper Use Case Small apps, APIs Large web apps

docs.title: 15. What to Learn Next
docs.text:
After Flask basics:

  • Blueprints
  • Flask-SQLAlchemy (database)
  • Flask-Login (authentication)
  • RESTful APIs
  • Deployment (Gunicorn, Nginx, Docker)

docs.title: 16. Summary
docs.text:
• Flask is a lightweight Python web framework
  • Easy to start, powerful when extended
  • Perfect for beginners and APIs
  • Grows with your project
